net.sf.mmm.util.version.api

Interface VersionIdentifier

  • All Superinterfaces:
    AttributeReadValue<String>, Comparable<VersionIdentifier>, Datatype, Serializable, SimpleDatatype<String>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractVersionIdentifier, VersionIdentifierImpl

    public interface VersionIdentifier
extends Comparable<VersionIdentifier>, SimpleDatatype<String>
    A VersionIdentifier is a version identifying a particular state of an object under version control. Such object can be an atomic asset like a single file but also a complex composition of many input artifacts like an entire software product.
    Since:
    3.0.0
    Author:
    Joerg Hohwiller (hohwille at users.sourceforge.net)

    • Field Detail

      • SNAPSHOT

        static final String SNAPSHOT
        The default indicator for a snapshot version.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • COMPARE_TO_STRICT_SUCCESSOR

        static final int COMPARE_TO_STRICT_SUCCESSOR
        This value indicates that a VersionIdentifier is a strict successor of another VersionIdentifier. A strict successor of VersionIdentifier V1 is a VersionIdentifier V2 that identifies a potential next release after V1.
        ATTENTION:
        An implementation can NOT predict the version history of a particular artifact. Therefore this is only an indicator whether a VersionIdentifier is a legal successor.
        E.g. for the version "1.2.3-RC4" strict successors are "1.2.3-RC5", "1.2.3-GA", "1.2.4", etc. while "1.2.3-RC6" or "1.2.4-RC2" are NOT.
        See Also:
        compareTo(VersionIdentifier), Constant Field Values

      • COMPARE_TO_STRICT_PREDECESSOR

        static final int COMPARE_TO_STRICT_PREDECESSOR
        The inverse relation to COMPARE_TO_STRICT_SUCCESSOR.

    • Method Detail

      • getVersionSegment

        int getVersionSegment(int index)
               throws IndexOutOfBoundsException
        This method gets an arbitrary segment of the version number. The version number is a part of the VersionIdentifier represented by the concatenation of all segments separated by a separator (typically the dot sign).
        This method will return 0 if a segment is not available. However it will not throw an IndexOutOfBoundsException if the index is non negative.
        Here are some examples
        version number getVersionSegmentCount() index getSegment(index)
        1.2.3.42 4 0 1
        1.2.3.42 4 3 42
        1.2.3.42 4 4 0
        4.0 2 0 4
        4.0 2 1 0
        4.0 2 2 0
        4.0 2 3 0
        E.g. if the version number is "1.2.3.42", then getSegment()
        Parameters:
        index - is the 0-based index of the requested segment. It shall not be negative.
        Returns:
        the requested segment. If not available (in other words if index is greater or equal to getVersionSegmentCount()) the value 0 is returned.
        Throws:
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the given index is negative.
        See Also:
        VERSION_SEGMENT_INDEX_MAJOR, VERSION_SEGMENT_INDEX_MINOR, VERSION_SEGMENT_INDEX_MILLI, VERSION_SEGMENT_INDEX_MICRO, VERSION_SEGMENT_INDEX_NANNO, VERSION_SEGMENT_INDEX_PICO

      • getVersionSegmentCount

        int getVersionSegmentCount()
        This method gets the number of segments of this VersionIdentifier .
        Returns:
        the number of segments.

      • getVersionMajorSegment

        int getVersionMajorSegment()
        This method gets the major segment of this VersionIdentifier. This is the most significant segment of the version. It only gets updated on significant functional and/or structural changes of the versioned artifact. An upgrade can cause appreciable manual effort and will often cause compatibility problems and require migration of data or configuration.
        Returns:
        the major version segment.
        See Also:
        VERSION_SEGMENT_INDEX_MAJOR

      • getVersionMinorSegment

        int getVersionMinorSegment()
        This method gets the minor segment of this VersionIdentifier. This is the second most significant segment of the version. It only gets updated on functional and/or structural changes of the versioned artifact. An upgrade should be supported but may cause compatibility problems and require migration of data or configuration.
        Returns:
        the minor version segment.
        See Also:
        VERSION_SEGMENT_INDEX_MINOR

      • getVersionMilliSegment

        int getVersionMilliSegment()
        This method gets the milli segment of this VersionIdentifier. This is the third most significant segment of the version. It only gets updated on small functional and/or structural changes of the versioned artifact. An upgrade should not cause problems but needs to be tested.
        Returns:
        the milli version segment.
        See Also:
        VERSION_SEGMENT_INDEX_MILLI

      • getVersionMicroSegment

        int getVersionMicroSegment()
        This method gets the micro segment of this VersionIdentifier. This is the fourth most significant segment of the version. It only gets updated on small internal changes (e.g. bugfixes) of the versioned artifact. An upgrade should not cause problems.
        Returns:
        the milli version segment.
        See Also:
        VERSION_SEGMENT_INDEX_MICRO

      • getPhase

        DevelopmentPhase getPhase()
        This method gets the DevelopmentPhase of this VersionIdentifier.
        ATTENTION:
        If the phase is undefined (null), DevelopmentPhase.RELEASE will be assumed for compareTo(VersionIdentifier).
        Returns:
        the DevelopmentPhase or null if NOT defined.

      • getPhaseAlias

        String getPhaseAlias()
        This method gets the string representation of the phase for this VersionIdentifier. This is ideally getPhase().toString() but may also be any other legal alias for the phase.
        E.g. for DevelopmentPhase.RELEASE the phase name may also be "final", "GA", "RTM", "REL", "gold", or "stable".
        Returns:
        the alias of the phase.

      • getPhaseNumber

        Integer getPhaseNumber()
        This method gets the subsequent number of this VersionIdentifier within a particular phase. It is typically null and will then be omitted in the string-representation. However release-candidates and updates are often numbered (e.g. like "u1", "u2", ... in Java-releases or "RC1"/"SR1", ... in Eclipse-releases).
        If getPhase() returns null also this method should return null. Also if getPhase() is DevelopmentPhase.RELEASE this method should return null (there is just one official release - after that there are updates).
        ATTENTION:
        If the phase is undefined (null), 0 will be assumed for compareTo(VersionIdentifier).
        Returns:
        the phase number or null if NOT defined.

      • isSnapshot

        boolean isSnapshot()
        This method determines if this VersionIdentifier indicates a snapshot release. A snapshot is an informal pre-release. Multiple snapshot releases with different content can be published for snapshot versions while this is strictly prohibited for non-snapshot versions. A snapshot version is a strict predecessor of the same VersionIdentifier without the snapshot.
        E.g. multiple "1.0.0-SNAPSHOT" versions can be published for testers. After all tests pass, the version "1.0.0" gets released. This approach is orthogonal to the phase and can be combined (e.g. "1.0.0-beta2-SNAPSHOT").
        Returns:
        true if this VersionIdentifier represents a snapshot release, false in case of an official release.

      • getRevision

        Long getRevision()
        This method gets the revision of the VersionIdentifier. It typically has a technical nature and might be derived from the underlying version control system.
        Returns:
        the revision or null if NOT defined.

      • getTimestamp

        Date getTimestamp()
        This method gets the timestamp of the VersionIdentifier. It indicates the point in time when this VersionIdentifier was assigned to the associated object. The timestamp may also called release date. The value is optional but is best practice to assign a timestamp to a VersionIdentifier.
        Returns:
        the timestamp or null if NOT defined.

      • getLabel

        String getLabel()
        This method gets the optional label of the VersionIdentifier. A label is a non-technical identifier also called code name (e.g. "Tiger" or "Dolphin").
        Returns:
        the label or null if NOT defined.

      • compareTo

        int compareTo(VersionIdentifier otherVersion)
        This method determines a (non-linear) distance from this version to the given otherVersion. It will return
        • COMPARE_TO_INCOMPARABLE if both versions are incompatible to each other (e.g. ).
        • 0 if both versions are historically equivalent (but may NOT be equal)
        • a negative value if this version is a predecessor of otherVersion. The value -1 indicates a strict predecessor.
        • a positive value if this version is a successor of otherVersion. The value +1 indicates a strict successor.
        The following table gives some examples:
        version otherVersion version.compareTo(otherVersion)
        1.0.0-SNAPSHOT 1.0.0-SNAPSHOT 0
        1.0.0 1.0.0-SNAPSHOT 1 (COMPARE_TO_STRICT_SUCCESSOR)
        1.0.1 1.0.0 1 (COMPARE_TO_STRICT_SUCCESSOR)
        1.0.1 1.0.0-SNAPSHOT >1
        1.6.0u23 1.6.0u24 -1 (COMPARE_TO_STRICT_PREDECESSOR)
        3.7-SR1-indigo 4.1.1-201109121510 <-1
        3.7.1-helios 3.7.1-indigo COMPARE_TO_INCOMPARABLE
        1.0-20000101T000000Z 1.0-19991231T235959Z COMPARE_TO_INCOMPARABLE
        1.0-20000101T000000Z 1.1-19991231T235959Z COMPARE_TO_INCOMPARABLE
        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface Comparable<VersionIdentifier>

      • toString

        String toString()
        This method gets a unique string representation of this VersionIdentifier. Returns the official String representation of this Datatype. While the general contract of Object.toString() is very weak and mainly used for debugging, the contract here is very strong. The returned String has to be suitable for end-users and official output to any kind of sink.
        ATTENTION:
        This method is not supposed to do internationalization (I18N). See NlsMessage for this purpose and implement NlsObject if you want to support I18N/L10N.
        Specified by:
        toString in interface Datatype
        Overrides:
        toString in class Object
        Returns:
        the official String representation to display the value of this Datatype.
